Combining brain–computer interface and virtual reality 
for rehabilitation in neurological diseases: 
A narrative review
Dong Wen, Yali Fan, Sheng-Hsiou Hsu, Jian Xu, Yanhong Zhou, 
Jianxin Tao, Xifa Lan, Fengnian Li
263-5905-00L 
Mixed Reality HS2025

Why BCI-VR for Neurorehab?
The Problem:
•
Traditional rehab: 
−
Monotonous
−
Passive Patient Role
−
Often modest gains
Dong Wen et al.
27.10.25
2
The Promise:
•
The BCI-VR Solution:
−
BCI: Direct brain→device, driving 
neuroplasticity
−
VR: Immersive world → multi-sensory 
feedback, engagement
Goal : Review 39 studies combining BCI + VR across paradigms and diseases
Claim : BCI-VR > traditional BCI for feedback & motivation, promising rehab gains

The Therapeutic Loop
A feedback loop that translates a user's brain intent into a virtual action.
Dong Wen et al.
27.10.25
3

The Therapeutic Loop (Contd.)
•
Loop: EEG → preprocess/feature → classifier → VR feedback → repeat
•
Inputs:
−
MI – Motor Imagery: Imagining body movements to generate brain signals 
(ERD/ERS) for motor control.
−
P300 – Event-Related Potential (300 ms): Detects attention to a target stimulus 
through a brainwave spike around 300 ms after stimulus.
−
SSVEP – Steady-State Visual Evoked Potential: Uses brain responses to 
flickering visual stimuli at fixed frequencies for control or communication.
•
Design principle: Low latency, artifact-robust, intuitive VR tasks
Dong Wen et al.
27.10.25
4

The Research Landscape
•
Paradigms: MI (18) > P300 (7) > SSVEP (5); others (9)
•
Diseases: 
−
Stroke leads
−
Also SCI, ADHD/ADD, AD/MCI, 
PD, schizophrenia
•
Why: 
−
MI/SSVEP → motor rehab/devices
−
P300 → attention/cognition/communication
•
VR value: 
−
Naturalistic scenes (homes & classrooms)
−
Gamified feedback
Dong Wen et al.
27.10.25
5

Evidence Highlights
•
Accuracy bands: System accuracies are often high, but depend heavily on the task and user.
−
MI: ~62–97%, P300: ~70–93.5%, SSVEP: ~81–95%
−
Some report ITR gains in VR
•
Boosters: Task simplicity, Robots/FES, Vibrotactile/haptics, Algorithm tuning
•
Takeaways:
−
Viable High Performance: VR matches flat-screen performance (~95% accuracy), proving its validity as a 
platform (Kathner et al.).
−
High MI Accuracy: Motor Imagery shows high accuracy (~90-95%) in both stroke patients and controlled lab 
settings (Achanccaray/Ortner, Munoz/Ma).
−
Powerful Robotic Synergy: Pairing with robotics is highly effective; a BCI-controlled ankle robot achieved 
80-100% success (Zeng et al.).
−
The Complexity Caveat: Accuracy drops significantly (to ~65%) as VR task complexity and immersion 
increases (Vourvopoulos et al.)
Dong Wen et al.
27.10.25
6

Evidence Highlights (Contd.)
Dong Wen et al.
27.10.25
7

Path Forward
•
Advantages: 
−
Richer feedback
−
Higher engagement
−
Ecological training
−
Potential faster learning
Dong Wen et al.
27.10.25
8
•
Challenges: 
−
EEG ITR
−
Artifact robustness
−
MI training burden
−
P300/SSVEP passivity/flicker comfort
•
Design cues: Naturalistic VR stimuli, Hybrid BCI+robot/haptics, Adaptive decoders
•
Bottom line: Promising but early, Clinical impact scales with robustness in 
performance and user-centered VR design
